ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Certificate dependent on Custom User Field
ResponsesInList.Text: In general the certificate activity works. Sometimes there may be some fuss in the details. The certificate module is designed to issue a certificate semi-automatically, so no one needs to create the certficate paper manually, check for prerequisites and send the paper to the participants. You should define clearly, what "having passed the course" means. Based on that definition the locking conditions should be configured in the certificate. Some thoughts on things that can happen: Students should be instructed that passing the course and receiving the certificate is a two-step operation. Students do not receive the certificate automatically after finishing the test, they have to open the certificate activity by themselves. Sometimes a certificate can be locked, allthough all conditions are met. In this case logging off and logging in again can do the trick. There are issues also discussed in this forum that certificates stay locked when teachers have changed the grade of a quiz manually. I think there is a fix for this. If the certificate shall be completely user-driven: you can always deactivate any locking options. Then everyone can obtain a certificate, as long as he is student in the course. If the certificate shall be completely teacher-driven: combine the certificate with an assignment activity. Students apply to the teacher that they want a certificate, and the teacher can grant it by giving the appropriate grade.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Using an interactive PDF as a certificate
ResponsesInList.Text: It doesn't look like this is possible. You can add values for the fields specified when adding a certificate to a Moodle course, but from what I could understand of the PHP code, you can't add you own fields ... interactive or otherwise. Interesting idea though! Gordon

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Using an interactive PDF as a certificate
ResponsesInList.Text: What is possible : Somebody with php knowledge can modify your certificate code so that questions are asked before certificate issue and the answers to this questions used on certificate printing. The problem is that to do that you will need to modify files outside of the /type subfolder of the certificate folder. And later when you would want to upgrade to a new certifictae version you would have to redo the changes at each upgrade . My opinion is that creating new certificates types (new subfolders in the /type subfolder) or adding new images in the /pix subfolder is safe because you can still upgrade your certificate mod later. But my advice is to avoid any modification outside of the /type and /pix subfolders because future upgrades will become a real pain. Or : 2nd solution You can't create a pdf (interactive or not) with some pdf creator software (like Adobe acrobat) and use that pdf during your certificate creation. The reason is that the TCPDF library that certificate module use to create the pdf is not able to do that. But there are other existing libraries (like FPDI + TCPDF or Zend PDF) that can merge several pdf. So here also a programmer should be able to create a modified certificate suiting your needs. As always with computer programming, nearly everything is possible ... with a good programmer (and the money to pay him). Please when you start such customized developpment, don't forget that later it will need some maintenance !!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Using an interactive PDF as a certificate
ResponsesInList.Text: ... and please consider contributing the code back to the certificate module for future generations

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Can we prevent Moodle 4.0.2 instructors from adding Old Certificate to courses?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Wallet Card
ResponsesInList.Text: I haven't actually done it yet... I just figured out how to do... I am in the process of building it now... Here is what you will need to do and hopefully it will work for you: 1. Navigate to to this folder in your moodle installation: mod/certificate/type 2. Create a new folder in this directory called "wallet". 3. Copy the certificate.php file in the letter_non_embedded to the directory you just created. 4. You will need to modify elements in this php file to get the position and size right for a wallet card. Get to know the contents of the file and things should start to become clearer as to what you need to modify. What this approach will do is allow the student to print out the wallet sized certificate on a regular letter sized peice of paper. They just need to cut it out and laminate it if they wish. In our design department they are making a mock-up with a dashed line to cut along. 5. Lastly, you will need to add a line to the language file of the certificate plugin to display the new certificate type correctly in the drop-down selector when you create a new certificate in the course. Navigate to mod/certificate/lang/en/ and open certificate.php 6. On line 164 you will see the default types included with the certificate plugin. Add a new line under 167 and put this there: $string['typewallet'] = 'Wallet'; Save your work and you should be good! Hope that helped, or at least got you on the right track =)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle 1.9: Certificate generated when quiz passed keeping same grade despite "Last Attempt" setting
ResponsesInList.Text: This is the cause of the problem: When your student completes a quiz and then clicks the certificate link in the course the Certificate module generates the certificate by inserting a new record into the certificate_issues table. This record contains various details about the certificate, including the DATE that the certificate was issued (certdate) and the GRADE that the student obtained (reportgrade). Then, if the certification requirements have been met (required grade, etc.), the PDF library in Moodle creates the certificate and displays it to the student. So far everything is great. Then the student goes and attempts the quiz again. When this second attempt is submitted the Certificate module adds another record to the grade_grades_history table with old values from the oldid , source , timemodified , itemid , rawgrade , rawgrademax and usermodified columns. Then it UPDATES the grade and timemodified values of the record in the quiz_grades table. Then it ADDS a new record to the quiz_attempts table containing the new attempt number , new grade , timestart , timefinish and timemodified values. Then it UPDATES the questions , sum_grades and grade column values of the original quiz record in the quiz table (the original submission). The next thing that the Certificate module SHOULD do is UPDATE the record for the original certificate (that was previously issued) on the certificate_issues table (which still contains the original reportgrade and certdate values). But the module DOES NOT do this last update and that is why the grade for the last attempt is not displayed! The module should be updating (or deleting???) the original certificate record on certificate_issues with the date and grade details of the most recent attempt that the student submitted. Alternatively, the certification date and grade details shouldn't even be stored on this table. Instead, the Certificate module should retrieve the latest grade details from the grade_grades table whenever the user requests the certificate. I think that this is a better solution... I haven't yet figured out what code needs to be updated to make sure that the above record update is performed, but this is, as far as I can see, the cause of the problem.

If I read the Xref documentation for Update_record() correctly this would update the record in the certificate_issues table with the most recent grade and date. If so, what would the second parameter for update_record() be?

I wanna customize the font for students' name, too. Could you help? Thanks a lot!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to make certificate not print course name? How to customize the font for students' name?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, I think you are confusing 2 different things language strings that are in files inside the lang subdirectory and defined by lines like $string['statement'] = 'has completed the course'; and data like the student name or the course name that are coming from the database and not from strings in lang files The right solution to customize your certificate is to modify the certificate.php file for your certificate type. For instance if you don't want 'has completed the course' to be printed on the certificate, you should not modify the $string['statement'] but rather remove the line that is printing it in your certificate.php file it should be something like certificate_print_text($pdf, $x, $y + 55, 'C', 'freesans', '', 20, get_string('statement', 'certificate')); just remove this line and this will remove the text on the certificate to remove the course name, remove the line that print it, it should be something like : certificate_print_text($pdf, $x, $y + 72, 'C', 'freesans', '', 20, $course->fullname); And to modify the font for student name you need to edit the line that looks like: certificate_print_text($pdf, $x, $y + 36, 'C', 'freesans', '', 30, fullname($USER)); to change the font change 'freesans' to another font used by the library that create the pdf (warning: you can't use any font that is installed on your computer, only fonts defined in the TCPDF libray and if your certificate has foreign characters you need to use a font that contain these characters or you will get question marks instead of characters) and to change the font size, change the 30 value to something else. Editing the language file should be avoided if possible because  when you will upgrade the certificate module in the future all your changes would be lost and would need to be re-done. I understand al this may seem difficult if you are unfamiliar with programming, so if you don't manage to do what you want, post your certificate.php and explain what you want to do and I will try to help you.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Change certificate Date format

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: add a Line
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi Beat, James is correct, the easiest way to add a line is by including it as an image. If you want another simple way, where the line is added during the creation of the PDF file, then you can use the following code in your certificate.php (located in the certificate type folder) Step 1 : Add the following line characteristics code anywhere in the beginning of the page: 
```text
$style1 = array('width' => 0.5, 'cap' => 'butt', 'join' => 'miter', 'dash' => 0, 'color' => array(0, 0, 0));
```
 This line of code indicates the following: line thickness of 0.5, Type of cap to put on the line is 'butt', type of line join is 'miter', dash pattern is 0 (straight line without dashes, if you wish to use dashes, increase this value to have a pattern. For example, the value 2 means 2 dashes on then 2 dashes off..), and finally the color in (R,G,B), (C,M,Y,K) or array(C,M,Y,K,SpotColorName). The 0,0,0 in this instance means black color. Step 2 : place the line command anywhere below the code "$pdf->AddPage();",  as follows: 
```text
$pdf->Line(10, 10, 285, 10, $style1);
```
 This will draw a line using the line characteristics specified in step 1, with the following dimensions: 10 (this is the horizontal start point) , 10 (this is the vertical start point) , 285 (this is the horizontal end point) , 10 (this is the vertical end point. since the beginning and end of the vertical points is the same, the line remains horizontal. If they are unequal, the line becomes slant) . Repeat step 2 as much as you want to generate lines. The same goes for vertical lines, where the horizontal start and end points remain constant and the vertical ones differ.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Create a new certificate model
ResponsesInList.Text: That's a very difficult one. The certificate module is not designed for this, and it would require more tweaking into its guts to make it work. It has something to do with the data the module can store for certificates and with the fact that the certificate is an activity. Activity instances can exist in only one course. What will not work: The certificate cannot contain references to more than one course (more precise: other courses than that the certificate is an activity in). What might work: Extra fields from the student user record can be added to the certificate. The standard certificate types only get data from the certificate issue table. When a student accesses the certificate and generates an issue by this, some data is copied into that table and then used to form the pdf-document.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: can't get logo to display
ResponsesInList.Text: FPDF seems to have problems with pictures that have transparacy. Possible solutions: Use a logo file without any transparancy (for example by removing the alpha channel) Change the palette mode from indexed colors to RGB-palette or vice versa Remember to disable "save certificate" in the certificate instance settings to force moodle to generate a new certificate after making changes. Otherwise a previously saved certificate is fetched from cache instead of a new one generated.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Site-Wide Reports
ResponsesInList.Text: No, you have not really understood how the roles system works. .../db/access.php just defines what capabilities exist. The bit above in yellow really only tells Moodle that there is a capability called'mod/certificate:view'. The rest is just details. You will see that $mod_certificate_capabilities is an array. You can define as many capabilities as you like by adding more elements to the array. When a plugin is installed or upgraded, the list of capabilities is loaded from .../db/access.php and stored in the database . Admins control which users have which capabilities by going to Admin -> Users -> Permissions -> Define roles in the Admin UI. (Some of the yellow details above are about setting the defaults for those admin settings.) The other things that affect what a user can do are what role assignments they have, and whether there are any role overrides. The place to put code like has_capability('mod/certificate:viewmycertificatesreport', get_context_instance(CONTEXT_SYSTEM)) is the place where it currently says is_primary_admin, and Kaalgat - told you to change it. However, if you are not very confident messing with PHP code, it may be better to wait for the maintainers of this bit of code to make the necessary changes, and release an updated version of the module.

ResponsesInList.Title: SVG vectorial image with ImageSVG()
ResponsesInList.Text:
I am sorry if this has been discussed before, but I couldn't find any relevant information using the site search. Looking at TCPDF website , one can easily make out that vector graphics is possible with TCPDF; however, the certificate activity is a bit limited in this area. I was able to use vector graphics directly into the certificate, and it works beautifully. No matter how big the certificate is scaled, it would retain its resolution. The problem is that the image upload option within moodle's certificate activity settings does not accept .svg file types. It is currently limited to .jpg and .png. This makes it difficult for course developers who are not admin users to change the graphics on the certificate as and when required. It would be great if the option to use .svg graphics is added to the certificate activity. The code would remain the same; however the image won't stretch, it will re-scale. This is an example of the code I have used to have a vector graphic background (border image) for my certificate: (the file I have edited is \mod\certificate\type\A4_non_embedded\certificate.php) 
```text
$pdf->ImageSVG($file='Certificate01.svg', $brdrx, $brdry, $brdrw, $brdrh, $link='', $align='', $palign='', $border=0, $fitonpage=false);
```
 Note that the Certificate01.svg file in this instance is placed at /mod/certificate/

ResponsesInList.Title: Big Mega-Oops
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Rhonda, please disregard my previous answer. I thought you wanted to change the format of the date printed on the certificate itself. To change the appearence of the date in the report view, you have to change the file %moodledir%/mod/certificate/report.php In this file, look for a line like $date = userdate($user->certdate); The userdate function here turns the numeric date stored in the database into a nicely formatted date. If no second parameter is given, the normal format for your locale is used ("Friday, the 4th ..."). You can override the format by adding a format string as a parameter: $date = userdate($user->certdate, "%m/%d/%Y, %Hh:%Mm"); I'm not sure what kind of quotes are right here. Check http://php.net/manual/en/function.strftime.php for possible format code characters Another hint: Look for a line beginning with $ sql sort $sqlsort = 's.certdate ASC'; sorts the certificate by date

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Adding a photo to the certificate
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Nikki, the certificate module for Moodle 2.1 don't use fpdf library, it uses the tcpdf library. As you will see here it is possible to use the tcpdf Image method with an image content rather than an adress. Unfortunately I can't give you "ready to run" code but just ideas to what you need to do : first get the file storage manager with the line : $fs = get_file_storage(); then get the files in the desired area (you need to pass the correct arguments : $contextid, $component, $filearea, and $itemid that you will have to find yourself depending where the picture is stored, looking at your plugin.php url, i think that $contextid = $instanceid; $component = 'mod_assignment'; $filearea = 'submission' ; $itemid=$userid; will do the job but you will need to test) $files = $fs->get_area_files($contextid, $component, $filearea, $itemid); then get the file content foreach ($files as $f) { $imgdata = $file->get_content(); } and lastly call tcpdf Image method but with an '@' as fist character : $pdf->Image('@'.$imgdata); Please, again, note this is absolutely untested code, I just wrote this looking at your message and I didn't verified anything, but I figured not many people would have an answer to your question, so better give you mine.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Adding a photo to the certificate
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Nikki, I had the time to look at the docs and here is a revised code, still untested, but more polished. It may still contain bugs but with some testing and debugging it should work. Don't forget to set debugging messages to developper level so that errors messages are displayed when you test this code. $fs = get_file_storage(); // Prepare file record object $fileinfo = array( 'component' => 'mod_assignment',     // usually = table name 'filearea' => 'submission',     // usually = table name 'itemid' => $userid,               // usually = ID of row in table 'contextid' => $instanceid, // ID of context 'filepath' => '/',           // any path beginning and ending in /

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Adding a photo to the certificate
ResponsesInList.Text: Well, I think there is at least a problem with the above code : as we are passing a data stream to the Image tcpdf method rather than a file address, it can't deduct the image type from the filename ! so I think that the line $this->Image('@'.$imgdata, 14, 18); should in fact be $this->Image('@'.$imgdata, 14, 18, 0, 0, 'JPEG'); if the document is a jpeg image Remarks : Of course you can use other image types : GIF, JPEG, PNG, BMP if you have the GD library installed on your server I hope all your images are of the same type, if not, you need to add code to change the last parameter depending on the $filename extension !

ResponsesInList.Title: Custom Cert. mysteriously issued certificates;
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I have something very mysterious that happened with CustomCert. And although it happened only once, and it may not happen again, I need to know what happened to ensure it will not happen in the future, as it caused a lot of confusion. I have done my best to figure out what happened from the front-end. In short, we upgraded Moodle. 1. Before the upgrade we were using LegacyCert. and were using Grades as a completion condition to receiving the certificate. 2. On July 6th, 2019 I added CustomCert for all students who have not yet received a Legacy Cert, so that the certificate they will be receiving from now on is a CustomCert not the LegacyCert, and removed access to generating a LegacyCert from all of these courses. 3. For many of these courses I continued to use grades as the completion condition for receiving the CustomCert. (For others I used the CourseCompletion as a completion condition for CustomCert, but that is not relevant here). 4. On July 11th, without the students logging in and without the students clicking to receive a Custom Cert CustomCert automatically issued a certificate to any user w ho was enrolled in a course that was using Grade Completion requirements and who had previously completed the grades completion requirement and received a Legacy Cert. It did not issue the certificates when the certificate was created (which might have made more sense), it issued them on a random date of July 11th. 5. What resulted was that any student who had already completed the course and received a Legacy Cert, was then issued a Custom Cert on July 11th. (The main issue we had with this, was not the student's receiving two certificates, but that certiticate completions are logged in Config. Reports and we then had duplicate records which caused a lot of problems...) 6. I understand that CustomCert does not "Issue" a certificate unless the student clicks on the "View Certificate" link. So I want to understand why it automatically issued certificates here. In short the main issue here is that CustomCert automatically issued certificates for student's who had completed its grade completion requirements, but had not clicked to "View Certificate." And it also did so on a seemingly random date without student log-in to trigger such an action. Assistance on this issue would be appreciated. Thanks!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Custom Cert. mysteriously issued certificates;
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Abe, I am moving over to the mod_customcert plugin from the original mod_certificate plugin, and I think I experienced the same thing. I think that the behavior of emailing certificates is fundamentally different between the two plugins. The old mod_certificate would not email a certificate until the user clicked the View certificate button. The customcert plugin, meanwhile, seems to email certificates immediately when it sees that the conditions are met (it does not wait for the student to click the button). Therefore, when I recently added the customcert module to a bunch of my courses that were previously using mod_certificate, all of the users who had a grade which met the condition for the certificate, were emailed a copy of the customcert. Thousands of people, all in the duration of a few minutes. Well, the "issue" event happened that quickly. It took longer for the email queue to clear out. Anyway, that is my experience, which maybe won't alleviate your overall concern, but hopefully makes it seem less random. - Ray

Upon testing the old certificates, they did not send to the additional email address. What I found is that the admin settings for the plugin do not update all of the certificates activities already in courses. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Where are the certificates stored on the server?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Does the Certificate link Directly to the quiz
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Smrithi I understand what you are trying to achieve. There maybe a simpler way of doing this (if so I would like to know too). This is what we do as our courses have an element of long answers that are graded manually. Student completes test (quiz) and receives automated advice from Moodle at the time of submission to allow 2-3 business days for the test (quiz) to be graded. Once graded, the teacher generates an email to the student by clicking on the student's name in Result - Overview We use Microsoft Outlook with the Insert - Signature feature, this email alerts the student to check their results, feedback and provides a screen shot example on how to retrieve their certificate. If all your courses are automated, then I can only suggest that you advise the student to check their results and download their certificate along with any other advice at the time they attempt the quiz and again after they submit thier quiz. Any notation can be inserted by editing the relevant quiz. Let me know how you go Nick

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Does the Certificate link Directly to the quiz
ResponsesInList.Text: If a quiz autogrades and if there is only one quiz I have attached an example of a useful default feed back to get them from quiz to certificate generation.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Does the Certificate link Directly to the quiz
ResponsesInList.Text: The certificate is designed to be downloaded/opened by the student after the locking conditions are met. The certificate cannot be pushed to the student. You should add a label or a text page into the course next to the test or the certificate that tells the students they can download the certificate by themselves after the test. If your test is a quiz and contains no freetext-questions (means: no teacher needs to grade it manually), the result is calculated right after the student submitted his attempt. After the attempt the students sees his general feedback, can browse his individual quiestion results and open the certificate as the next activity. After you created the certificate activity, you can also put a link to the certificate activity in the introduction of the quiz.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Upgrade from 2011110101 to 2012070201
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Michael, If you have not edited the mod/certificate folder, then yes you can delete it and place the new certificate folder in it's place. The files in the mod/certificate folder do not contain the information about who has received the certificate, what the conditions are etc, that is stored in the database. So deleting this folder does not uninstall the certificate module. The folder simply contains the code that determines how the certificate behaves. You can also place pictures here, and edit the certificate types, which change how the certificate appears, but if you have not altered the default types and images then you will not lose any vital information. There is a file mod/certificate/db/upgrade.php that contains a set of instructions on what to do during the upgrade of certificates. When you replace the mod/certificate folder with the new version, this file will be updated and perform the necessary database changes to work with the new code. Regards, Mark

ResponsesInList.Title: Sort by Date
ResponsesInList.Text: Moodle 2.4.3 My awarded certificates are on multiple pages, sorted by first name.  Does anyone know a way to have these sort by completion date?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Sort by Date
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm assuming you are displaying the list of certificates from the 'view nnn issued certificates' link and when downloading to CSV with the link at the bottom of the screen display list you get a text date you can't sort on? If so. you can make code changes as sugest in this post: https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=152938 or there is a fairly easy way to convert the text date in the downloaded excel report to numeric date you can sort just using Excel functions (I have Excel 2013 - location of functions may be a little different in other versions) Part 1 - remove the day and time from the date text string using Text to Columns insert 2 blank columns to the right of the text date column Select the date column and click Text To Coumns from the Data tab  - use Delimted and Comma to split into 3 columns based on the comma location (filling the 2 blank columns inserted) Delete the columns with the Day and Time text leaving just the date (still in text formn Part 2  - convert the text date to a new numeric date column for sorting using the DATEVALUE formula insert a column after the trimmed date column and format for dates - lets say this is column F in cell F2 (assuming headers in row 1) - enter the formula '=DATEVALUE(e2)'  - hit enter. It should put an equivalent numeric date with the formatting you applied in column F copy the formula down all cells in coumn f do a custom sort by column F PS - if you to want the column to have the actual numeric date values instead of a formula,  just copy the column of formula values and do a Paste Special / Values into a blank column then you can delete the text and formula columns This post also has code changes you can make if this is an option for you: https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=152938

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Certificate-"Minutes required in course" option missing in 2.+++
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Ronald, I have only taken the position of maintainer after the migration to Moodle 2.0, so it was not my decision to take out this functionality. Basically, in 1.9 there was a table in the database called 'certificate_linked_modules' that linked the certificate with certain modules (eg. a quiz) and contained a grade value that must be met before the certificate could be accessed. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Certificate-"Minutes required in course" option missing in 2.+++
ResponsesInList.Text: HI Larry, There is a function in mod/certificate/lib.php called certificate_get_course_time that handles this functionality. It is pretty much identical to the function used in 1.9. It basically looks in the log table for any activity in a particular course for a specific user, it then adds up the difference in time between each activity for a single login. So, if a user clicks to view an activity, this will get logged, then say they look at this activity for 5 minutes and then click back on the course link the function will say that 5 minutes has been spent on that course. Regards, Mark

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Certificate-"Minutes required in course" option missing in 2.+++
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks for that description, but it gets me to the root issue with another question. What is of most interest is whether this function can tabulate cumulative time across multiple logins; e.g., a student who does part of a course one day, shuts down his computer, then logs in and completes the course the next day.  When you say that it "adds up the difference in time for each activity for a single login," I infer that it does not accumulate time for prior logins, and that the time that is added up starts with the most recent login.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Certificate-"Minutes required in course" option missing in 2.+++
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Larry, The code works the same way it was working in certificate for Moodle 1.9 : 2 differents actions in the log table are considered as part of the same login session if they are separated by a time lesser that the session timeout value and time are only added between actions part of the same session. So In your case if the student does part of a course one day, shut his computer and log and complete the course next day the time of the first session would be from his first login to his latest action this day no more. But you need to be aware of the way the calculation is done because if for instance session timeout is set to 1 hour on your Moodle website, and if a student login, do some action in the course, shut his computer, then login again 45 minutes later and do some action, he will be considered as having spend 45 minutes in course because all actions will be considered as part of the same session. Unfortunately I see no way to avoid that.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Certificate positioning co-ordinates
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi, The units are defined in the certificate template, when instantiating the PDF object. E.g. for .mod/certificate/type/A4_embedded/certificate.php, there's the line: 
```text
$pdf = new PDF($certificate->orientation, 'mm', 'A4', true, 'UTF-8', false);
```
 The second argument ('mm' - millimetres) sets the units. Your certificate probably uses the same. HTH , Dave.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Certs being assigned to all users regardless of completion
ResponsesInList.Text: Have you set up any access restrictions for the certificate module? When you enable the email option, a certificate will be issued and emailed to all users who can access the certificate. If the certificate is not set to "Hide", and it does not have any restriction on it (grade, date, activity completion, etc.), then it is available for students to access. This section of the documentation describes in a little more detail: https://docs.moodle.org/37/en/Custom_certificate_module#Email_students.2Fteachers.2Fothers

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Import user data to create certificates
ResponsesInList.Text: I was able to finally figure out how to do this. Here is the process we used in case anyone else wants to do the same. 1, Go to the course in question, and "export" the gradebook with names of enrolled users and the activities where you want to enter grades (in our case, this was the final exam empty fields). 2. Open up the exported file in Excel and bulk enter a passing grade for all the users in the final exam (we used 100%); save as a CSV file. 3. Import the gradebook file back into Moodle, making sure you map the fields correctly. 4. Temporarily delete ALL of the restrictions on the Certificate; new certificates should then be automatically generated for each user with the new data (you may have to purge cache); if you have checked the option to e-mail certificates, they will be immediately sent out. 5. Re-enter the restrictions back on the Certificate so that all new users on Moodle will now have to meet the requirements to get their certificate.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: pdf certificate spans on six pages
ResponsesInList.Text: Perhaps you should undo the changes in line 932 in lib.php The basic function Cell() is defined in /lib/tcpdf/tcpdf.php and uses 0 as a default value for the second parameter. The parameters 500 and 0 (resp. 120) define the size of the box that tcpdf puts the text into. I'm not sure what unit size the second parameter is measured with. I assume 123 makes the box so big that it automatically casts extra pages. So you should restore the old value and modify the mod/certificate/mytype/certificate.php if you want to lower the text on paper.
